Sound the charge! We will make the very heavens tremble and shake! -- The term "Cataphract" comes from the Greek verb "kataphrattein", which means "to cover something in iron", and the word is perfectly fitting for this unit: both horse and rider are completely covered in thick and heavy chainmail and plate armour, hiding from sight everythig but the eyes and the hooves. Arrows bounce harmlessly against such protection, and the combined weight of flesh and iron makes the cataphracts a slow but unstoppable force. The the ground quakes under the sheer weight, and everything in their path is mercilessly trampled under them: not even spearmen can stop such a relentless killing machine. The horses used by cataphracts are strong and priceless purebreeds, hailing from the plains of inner Anatolia: should those plains fall into the hands of the enemy, surely the Byzantine army -and with it the Empire- would suffer a devastating blow
Only the bravest are chosen to be the champions of their tribes.

An Iqta holder can, and usually did in the Seljuq and Khwarazmid periods, have a military obligation to the one who granted it to him. The 'fief' would also stipulate how many soldiers a Muqta would have to provide to his overlord in war. Cavalrymen were a typical kind of soldier requested in Iqtas, and Iran had a rich history of mounted combat. Mounted Sarbaazan (soldiers) are shown, in miniatures, as wielding a weapon in one hand, quite commonly a sword, and a round sipar shield in the other, generally made of hardened leather. A kalkan shield (wicker shield) would have been a possibility. The tabarzin, or saddle axe, was also a very popular weapon amongst Eastern Muslim cavalrymen in the medieval era.

The first possible recorded instance of Mercenaries serving an Omani Imam was in the reign of Imam al Muhanna bin Jayfar (840-851 AD). During the Julanda revolt, Ahmad al-Izkawi in Misbah al-Zalam indicated that the Army of Sohar sent against them included Indians. There is not enough detailed information about the "Hindi" army to know whether they were Indians who lived in Sohar or been brought from Sind as Mercenaries. ('Ism 'Ali Ahmed al-Rawas, Early Islamic Oman - (ca - 622/280-893) a Political History (University of Durham, October 1990) p. 264-265)Between the political doctrines of the Ibadi, there were the Shira, and the Difa. Shira was based on Qur’anic verses which speak of men selling themselves and their goods in this life for God's cause in return for God's pleasure and for Paradise. It It involved Khuruj , coming out against oppression and tyranny, where the Shurah are assembled under the leadership of an Imam. The defensive Difa' situation was more or less an extension of the Shira, when Khuruj expanded to war, or when the Ibadis were attacked. A military leader could be elected, Imam al-Difa', but his authority was restricted. Only the Imam az-Zuhur had all the authority, rights and Obligations reserved to the office. He could call uponall able-bodied men to fight, and could reinforce this army with slaves when required. The later Yaarubid Dynasty maintain a standing Mercenary and Slave army, even though highly criticized due to Ibadi's rejection of standing army under a ruler, as later the Shurah died out (Patricia Risso Dubuisson, A history of Uman and Masqat, c. 1750-1800. (Institute of Islamic Studies, McGill University, 1982)  p. 42, 44)
The chance to improve their social position makes these men fierce opponents.
These men defend their lord, against heretics and usurpers alike!
These men do not need heavy armour, their skill with a blade protects them.
The levy are peasants drafted to fight. They oil the machine of war.
Hardy steppe archers better able to defend themselves than most bowmen.

During the Medieval Era, the Rus use the  title "Tsar" to refer to foreign Emperors rather than their own. The title "tsar" was occasionally used by Ivan III (ruled 1462-1505), and his son Vasili III (1505-1533). It only started to be formally used as the title of the Russian Sovereign in 1547, by Ivan IV.
Awam are the common folk, the laity, the unwashed masses.

Over the course of the Middle Ages, from the eighth to the fifteenth centuries, thousands of Christian soldiers from the Iberian Peninsula traversed the Mediterranean to serve in the armies and courts of Muslim rulers in al-Andalus and North Africa. Not only did the use of Christian soldiers by these Islamic kingdoms span a period of centuries, the practice is also well documented in both Latin and Arabic sources. According to al-Umari in the 14th century, the Marinid army employed 4000 Franks. Ibn Khaldun recorded that Maghribi realms employ Christian Foreign Legions as an anchor to their battle lines, to hold firm in close formation as a place for the roaming hit-and-run Maghribi cavalry can retreat into safety. The Maghribi realms does this because even if this means employing infidels, Europeans were the best people they know of for close-rank fighting in formation. However, they were best used for Muslim vs Muslim wars; not in wars against Christians because they might defect! (Abd Ar Rahman bin Muhammad ibn Khaldun, ‘Al-Muqaddimah’ Chapter III, Section 35 on Wars and the methods of waging war practiced by the various nations) (Globalization of Knowledge in the Post-Antique Mediterranean, 700–1500, p. 102; Maya Shatzmiller, 'Marīnid Fez: The Economic Background of the ‘Quest for Empire’ (2008) p. 14)

Piyadegan was the general term for foot soldiers. Iranian infantry is mostly illustrated using spears or an assortment of one-handed weapons such as axes, maces and straight swords, along with round shields.
A warrior grasps the spear firmly, so that it does not shake in his hand.
In the vastness of the desert, the speed to be everywhere at once can be decisive.
Chukhchi/Ch’ukhch’arkhi - Royal Guard. ("Kartlis Tskhovreba". Georgian National Academy of Sciences Commission for the study of Georgian Historical Sources (Artanuji, 2014) 281, 402).

Mohajeman, 'raiders', were traditionally used as a vanguard, and filling numerous important roles. Acting as scouts, to provide information on the enemy, and as pillagers in enemy territory to destroy local logistical support and terrorizing the local population. In battle, such light cavalry would use their bows to break enemy formation, then draw weapons and charge at isolated groups.
A wise warrior never leaves home ahead of their axe.
Vandals value bravery and disregard the wellbeing of others.
The wolves are on the hunt. Eternally.
These reins in Spain fight mainly on the plain.

Several semi-nomadic peoples of the eastern lowlands exclusively used Bows, such as the Simt of Tigray, Arho of Eastern Shewa, and Maya of Fatagar and Waj. The Maya especially used longer arrows according to Shihab ad-Din, possibly shot from a longbow; Manuel Barradas also stated there were Ethiopians who used the longbow, even though not stating which people exactly. Alvarez however felt the lack of fletching on their arrows reduces accuracy. The most terrifying of the Maya was their use of poisons - Ethiopian Emperors had regiments who specialized using it. The Maya Bowmen were mercenarial in their service, and when Ibrahim al-Gazi came, they did a heel-turn and changed sides - as they were initially a conquered people turned vassal state.  ( Merid W. Aregay, 'A Reappraisal of the Impact of Firearms in the History of Warfare in Ethiopia (C. 1500-1800), Journal of Ethiopian Studies , JANUARY 1980, Vol. 14, p. 98-99 )
Fighting effectively at sea takes skill, courage, and sea-legs in abundance.
The edges of Makuria are along great tracts of wilderness, bordered by hostile powers and peoples. It seems only fitting they should be protected by equally wild men.
The very core of the late Roman army, these spear-armed infantrymen are Legionaries in all but name.

Bahlul Khan Lodi being a great admirer of Mongol bravery and quality as soldiers, he settled many princes and kept a large retinue of Mongol soldiers called the Khasa Khali, on top of recruiting several thousand into the royal army.
The circumstances of your birth are irrelevant, know only that you must fight, and you must fight now.

The first fully ocean going ship in Europe, the Carrack is a four-masted vessel developed in the Mediterranean during the 15th century, and later used throughout Europe. Carracks were ocean-going ships: large enough to be stable in heavy seas, and roomy enough to carry provisions for long voyages. They were usually square-rigged on the foremast and mainmast and lateen-rigged on the mizzenmast. They had a high rounded stern with large aftcastle, forecastle and bowsprit at the stem. As the forerunner of the great ships of the age of sail, the carrack was one of the most influential ship designs in history
Armoured cavalry, charging the battle line; the very embodiment of Frankish ambition.

2/3rds of an Amir's Iqta revenue has to be for the recruitment and maintenance of his retinue, and that must include a number of both Mamluk and non-Mamluk horsemen. (Heath, Ian, "Armies of the Middle Ages, Volume 2: The Ottoman Empire, The Eastern Europe, and the Near East 1300-1500" (Wargames Research Group, 1984) p. 40-41) The number of Mamluk an Amir may have depends on his rank; the lowest is Amir of 5, followed by Amir of 10 and 20. Amir al-Tablkhanah or Amir with a Marching Band may have 40 to 80 Mamluks. The highest Amir was the Amir Mi'a Muqaddam Alf, or the Amir of 100 Mamluks and Commander of 1000 horsemen. (David Ayalon, Studies on the Structure of the Mamluk Army II, Bulletin of the School of Oriental and African Studies, University of London, Vol.15, No. 3 (1953), pp. 467-470)
Three weeks a year, the woodcutter finds an alternative use for his axe.
These man carry a falx, nothing more. They need nothing more.
The young wolf lacks the wisdom of his elder, but none of the vigour.
Armed with spear and javelin, these warriors are a force to be reckoned with.
Fighting effectively at sea takes skill, courage, and sea-legs in abundance.
Even at the Bridge of Judgement, the Gyan-Avspar will fight for the king.
These men keep their prince alive. It is their sole purpose.
The Berber people are ordered by their lord to fight, and to die at his command.
Andalusian natives in the service of the caliphate, killing for religion or for coin.

A lower ranking member of the Teutonic Order, typically a person of common birth, Diendebrudern could be local administrators or military leaders especially of infantry levies. Diendebrudern wore a gray habit with a T-shaped cross.
These men are trained from youth to be strong, to fight, and to defend at all costs their lord and master.
Tribal people, called from the vast lands of the steppes to fight.

There was at least 1000 Frankish Cavalry at the reign of Kaykhusraw II. These Cypriot, French, German, Italian were commanded by a Kondistabl, who were not necessarily Latin, for instance Michael VIII Palaiologos once hold the office. At Kose Dag, at least 2000 of those western cavalrymen were present (Ian Heath, Armies and Enemies of the Crusades 1096-1291 (Wargames Research Group, 1978) p, 20)
The ship cuts through the water like a sword cuts through flesh.
The backbone of Imperial might. These men march on frontiers, carrying the Empire to distant lands.

The Sling remained popular in the Maghreb long after it had fallen by the wayside in other kingdoms. Its use by native Berber peoples was transmitted into Al-Andalus where it remained in use as a effective weapon well into the 1400s.
These men have a particular set of skills. They will find you, and they will kill you.
The force of the spear is tenfold when braced by a steed.
Experts in reconnaissance, these men reveal the lie of the land ahead of the army.

Turkish groups of nomads had migrated into Khwarazm peacefully before the 13th century, and had also followed the Seljuqs in their conquest of Iran. Many had been settled and would bring their military skill to battle for the rulers and leaders they felt loyal to. Turkish skill in archery is well-known and even though a true Turk does not usually fight on foot, he does if the situation calls for it.

Turkoman armies in the later medieval period still kept, for the most part, numerous aspects of tribal organization. Cavalry remained the largest contingent of Qara Qoyunlu and Aq Qoyunlu armed forces and the main 'regular' corps of such forces were Tirkash-band, 'quiver-bearers', horse archers mostly drawn from the settled turkish tribal societies.
Sogdians are keen in the ways of war; a camel is but another weapon.

Incendiary weapons became a mainstay of the battles during the Crusades, most importantly in siege warfare. Nafta grenades were the favoured weapons of the Muslims, even being imported all the way into India. Dedicated soldiers would be tasked with using such dangerous weapons and wear special coats less vulnerable to the flames.

The Awlad an-Nas were the sons of Mamluks, free Muslims by birth unlike their fathers. Therefore, they cannot join the prestigious ranks held by Mamluks; as freeborns are inferior in status in the Realm of the Mamluks. In the Army, they comprised the elites of the Ajnad al-Halqa. The Awlad an-Nas may rise to become an Amir when the Sultan need them to curb the influence of some Mamluk faction. (David Ayalon, Studies on the Structure of the Mamluk Army II, Bulletin of the School of Oriental and African Studies, University of London, Vol.15, No. 3 (1953), pp. 456; Heath, Ian, "Armies of the Middle Ages, Volume 2: The Ottoman Empire, The Eastern Europe, and the Near East 1300-1500" (Wargames Research Group, 1984) p. 42)
What these ships may lack in size, they make up for in manoeuvrability.
A lord must be certain that his back is being watched.

They represented the Arab Badawi settlers of the Banu Hilal, Banu Sulaym, and Banu Maqil, famous for their devastating invasion and migration to the Maghrib. Rebellious and unruly, they often clash with the local Berber governments such as the Almohads and Marinids. They were quickly integrated in the army so as to keep them occupied and controlled. During the rule of Caliph Abu Yaqub Yusuf, the military value of the Arabs was reflected in their salaries which were higher than those of other troops in the Almohad army. Here, they are represented as light lancers, as Arabs prefers the lance compared to the Berbers who prefers the Javelins and the Turks with the bows. (Pascal Buresi, Hicham El Aallaoui, Travis Bruce. Governing the Empire. Provincial Administration in the Almohad Caliphate (1224-1269): Critical Edition, Translation, and Study of Manuscript 4752 of the asaniyya Library in Rabat Containing 77 Taqadim ("Appointments"). Brill, 3, pp.xxviii et 540, 2012, "Studies in the History and Society of the Maghrib". p. 174-175; Amar Salem Baadj, The Struggle for North Africa between Almohads, Ayyubids, and Banū Ghāniya: Late Twelfth to Early Thirteenth Centuries A.D (University of Toronto, 2013) p. 110; Ian Heath, Armies of Feudal Europe 1066-1300 (Wargames Research Group, 1989) p.24; Francisco García Fitz (ed.), João Gouveia Monteiro (ed.), War in the Iberian Peninsula, 700-1600 (Routledge, 2018) p. 14)
A wall of spears, ideal for facing down charging cavalry units.
No wind, no trees, no barriers; the desert is the perfect place to fire a bow.
When one wolf dies, the pack avenges him.
These men defend Augustus with the strength of the legendary demigod.
Skirmishers perform a useful tactical function. Sometimes that function is merely to distract the enemy.
Taught to shoot as soon as they can walk, Avar tribesmen can handle a bow, if nothing else.

The Maluyyun Guard of the Nasrid Emirs of Granada shared the same background as any foreign or slave guards in the Muslim realms of the Medieval Era: The need to have an elite cadre of guards free from political, familial, or tribal ties to factions that may oppose the monarch. This loyalty was boosted by the their separation from their families, from their native environment, and their religion from early age when they were more malleable to education. Instead of Turks or Circassian like the Mashriqi Mamluks, or Black Africans of the Abid al-Makhzan, the Maluyyun recruits come from Captives in wars or raids against Castille; or from European slaves, brought up as Muslims. The guard, either slave or free Christian foreign legion in nature, need to be differentiated from the Christian mercenary companies which were contracted temporarily.(Ana Echevarria, Knights on the Frontier: The Moorish Guard of the Kings of Castille 1410-1467 (Brill, 2009) p.88-94)
Fighting effectively at sea takes skill, courage, and sea-legs in abundance.
Enemies run amok when these horsemen take to the field.

Crossbow were so popular in Andalusia since the 11th century, Ibn Said al-Maghribi stated that crossbow was the common Andalusian's foot soldiers' equipment. Ibn al-Khatib in the 14th century claimed that Crossbow were more widely used in Andalusia than traditional Arabic hand bows. Hernando de Pulgar, the royal historian of Castille in the late 15th century praised the Granadine's skill with the weapon, saying that they trained since childhood. Crossbow shooting clubs can be found in every Andalusian cities, providing ready reserves of crossbowmen for the last line of defense of Granada.Well-armored foot crossbowmen with scale and helmets, some behind mantlets or tower shields, appear in many depictions of sieges in Al-Andalus.(Ian Heath, Armies of Feudal Europe 1066-1300 (Wargames Research Group, 1989) p.106-107; Ian Heath, Armies of The Middle Ages: Volume 1 (Wargames Research Group, 1982) p. 135)

First handguns appeared in Serbia in the beginning of the 15 century. Rich gold and silver mines enabled Despots to buy cutting-edge technology and hire experts to wield it.At this stage, however, handguns (Serbian - puška) made more of morale than physical damage. They were hard to aim precisely and had limited range ( but if target was hit - shot would go through almost any armor ). However- thundering sounds, violent flashes, and awful smells would scare men and horses alike. These men are professional soldiers. Most of them are locals, but some are mercenaries from Hungary. Shields are not used and their mail and brigandine armors are only protection. Their secondary weapon of choice is usually sabre, but if it has to be used - battle is not going well.
The toughest, bravest men the north has to offer.

Yaya = Literally "Pedestrians", the first semi-regular footsoldiers of the Ottoman Army, drafted 1 man out of 25 households, given tax exemption. Reportedly proposed by Alaeddin Pasha and Candarli Kara Halil Pasha in 1325. (Heath, Ian, "Armies of the Middle Ages, Volume 2: The Ottoman Empire, The Eastern Europe, and the Near East 1300-1500" (Wargames Research Group, 1984) p. 4.; Uyar, Mesut "A Military History of the Ottomans: From Osman to Attaturk" (ABC-CLIO, 2009) p. 29, 50)
In the name of the king, these men will keep order and mete out justice.
Justice at the end of a blade.
If it's out there, these men will find and make use of it.
This thing could probably launch a fortress, given the chance.
These men were terrifying long before the mushroom told its tale.

The mozarabs, or the Christian inhabitants of Islamic Andalusia had gradually become more and more culturally distinct from their pre-Islamic ancestors, to the point where they oftentimes appeared to be more similar to their Berber and Arab rulers than the native Iberian kingdoms to the north.

'Urban at-Ta'a = "Obedient Arabs" Bedouin Nomads loyal to the central authority, serving as light cavalry, scouts, raiders, and screening force. Some Arab tribes were tasked with supplying horses to the Barid postal service, and guarding roads south to Sudan. Mamluk-Bedouin Arab relation are not a smooth one, as the tribes tend to be unruly and disobedient. The Mamluks did not refrain from employing the harshest and cruellest measures in order to suppress the revolting Urban. Unfortunately for the Mamluks it is to no avail, the 'Urban keep revolting - they dominated Upper Egypt and Sudan, and in 15th, even spread their power over Lower Egypt (David Ayalon, The Auxiliary Forces of the Mamluk Sultanate, p.23-31) Each region fielded draws different composition of auxiliaries, with Egyptian and Damascene armies utilizing most of the Bedouins of Central Arab and Egyptian Delta (R. Stephen Humphreys,The Emergence of the Mamluk Army I, Studia Islamica , 1977, No. 45 (1977) p. 73)

While only lightly trained and equipped, levies can form a large source of manpower in emergencies. The traditional weapons of Armenians, the bow and spear, are the most natural for the common man to be wielding.

The mainstay of the Republic's land armies, swordsmen are expected to hold the line and kill in the name of Venice "An old motto recited by Venice's elders recited "seed the sea, it will bear better fruits than the earth", and following it the Republic never colonised much land, preferring the control of the major trade routes over far-stretching domains. However, with enemies lurking just the other side of the lagoon, the need for a regular land army arises more than ever, and lines over lines of swordsmen are sent into the fray: trained and equipped taking money from the bottomless coffers of Venice, these men can dispatch the enemies of the Most Serene with ease, and resist heavy assaults for a prolonged time".
These blue-haired, tattooed warriors strike fear into their enemy's hearts.
Man's best friend can also be a savage, terrible enemy.
In the hands of skilled men, axes are terrifying weapons.
Fighting effectively at sea takes skill, courage, and sea-legs in abundance.

The Shabankara are a confederation of major Kurdish clans in Western Iran, along the Zagros mountains. The Hazaraspids are a Shabankara dynasty that took power in Lurestan and can rely on tribesmen from those mountainous areas as a source of reliable manpower. Lightly armoured, tribesmen can use the terrain to their advantage, ambushing enemies, peppering with missiles before charging with axe and shield.

According to the Life of Täklä Havmanot the king of Damot, Motälami, had his own regiments, one of which this Ge'ez document calls the hära sägärät. something like royal bodyguard (Merid W. Aregay, 'Military Elites in Medieval Ethiopia' Journal of Ethiopian Studies, Vol. 30, No. 1 (June 1997), pp. 41)
Although slower than a bow, a crossbow bolt can fell most living things.
Table Men are the highest rank of Norwegian King's Hird, comprised of Lendmann. They were allowed to sit on the King's table.. After 1277 they become Miles or Knights
Fighting effectively at sea takes skill, courage, and sea-legs in abundance.
In times of war peasants are forced from their farms and drafted into levies. Unsurprisingly, peasants are undisciplined troops who are better at fleeing than they are fighting.
With strength and fortitude, these men will stand against any foe.
Fighting effectively at sea takes skill, courage, and sea-legs in abundance.

Andalusian emirs disliked the foreign Berber warlords that regularly moved through their territories. One particular point of contention was these rulers requiring that the local emirs raise conscripts for their holy wars against the Christians. Sometimes, they grudgingly obliged. Other times, they did not.

Slave-soldiers, Ghulams or Mamluks were the property of rulers and Amirs, acting as their elite retinue. Fiercely loyal and trained for years, they could fight with a large number of weapons with extreme proficiency and rose to very high ranks in military command and administrative duties. They were notably famous for their skill on horseback, firing arrows at high rates while on the move.
Slowly, slowly, catchy filthy barbarian scum…
A mob is just that until pointed at your enemy. Then they're an army.
Best deployed at range, they will suffer heavy losses if kept in melee.
Whatever you may hear, there are none more fierce than the Dawser.

Iranians and Northern Indians were known to have used various types of very large shields made of wicker or reed, practically mantlets, when in sieges. The purpose was to provide cover for missile troops or to form a 'roof' over sappers and engineers that worked on weakening the walls.

Greek fire was a mix of liquid chemicals that could be siphoned from a cauldron, sprayed through a tube and then ignited. It was capable of clinging fast to any material and could burn through the flesh of a man in seconds. The flames were seemingly inexhaustible, and its victims had little hope of putting them out as dousing with water was futile. Greek fire was able to burn both on and under water, making it a highly-effective naval weapon, but one which could easily get out of control and destroy its users. Those brave enough to try could create a sheet of flame that rapidly consumed any ships it touched.

Pushan-dar or Pushan-push means "Man-in-Armour" or "Clad-in-Armour" Pushan-dar formed the heavily armoured contingents of Irano-Turkoman militaries. The 14th century saw a greater differentiation between Arabic and Iranian military fashions, with the latter gaining much more Central Asian influence due to the Mongol conquest. Helmets became more elongated, culminating in a tip, limb protection became extremely common, especially for the arms and large, round wicker shields are in almost every depiction of Iranian soldiers. Metal plates also made their appearance, though usually sewn into fabric armour, such as brigandines. (Sabuhi Ahmadov, Knights in Azerbaijan, Article 4, 15th-17th centuries, IRS History, 2 (7) Summer 2014. pg. 47)  (V. Minorsky, A Civil and Military Review in Fārs in 881/1476,  Bulletin of the School of Oriental Studies, University of London, Vol. 10, No. 1 (1939),pp. 155, 156. 164)
Robbery and plunder - and the skills they require - can be usefully applied on the battlefield.
One axe can topple a tree. Many can level the forest.
To fight and maybe die, when the alternative is certain death, motivates the levied man somewhat.
Having settled on its territory, these noble tribesmen fight for Rome in return.
Best deployed at range, these horse archers should be kept from melee whenever possible.
With swords and slings, they can attack from afar or hand-to-hand.

Pasdaran ('guards') are the last line of defense for a Shah. The role of personal bodyguards would typically fall to the most trusted of a ruler's soldiers, which would naturally be from the Ghulam troops in medieval Islamic kingdoms. Sources on the use of polearms East of Europe are sparse, but documents from visitors to the East and some few surviving artefacts would indicate that Muslim kingdoms also developed some weapons of that nature.
Fighting effectively at sea takes skill, courage, and sea-legs in abundance.

Large dhows for high-sea trade on deep waters. Baghlahs were widely used in the past centuries as merchant ships in the Indian Ocean and the minor seas around the Arabian Peninsula. They reached eastwards to Sindh, India and up to the Bay of Bengal and further beyond as far as the Spice Islands. Southwestwards they reached down to the East African coast
A heavy warship, the dromont is the master of the waves.
Camels confuse and baffle, but if anyone can ride them, Persians can.

The only peoples to value horses more than Nubians were their Arab rivals, who could field great quantities of them. These men are a vital middle ground between the lumbering heavy horse and the swarms of semi-nude warriors that otherwise encompass Makurian armies.
The ship cuts through the water like a sword cuts through flesh.
PLACEHOLDER

Squires are used to do what a knight would consider too low, and mounted sergeants are used to do what a squire would consider too low even for him -- "Since common peasant couldn't afford a horse, but there was still the need for a rapid scout unit (and noble knights considered scouting a dishonourable task), trusted sergeants who showed cunning behaviour were given second-choice horses and used as a light and fast cavalry force, usually sent ahead of the main army to scout the area and harass enemy light troops or carriages. Being fast, they can easily outmanoeuver infantry and heavy cavalry, allowing them to hit fast and hard unprotected targets such as archers or supply convoys, but they should never be used against actual cavalry and trained infantry."

Turkish groups of nomads had migrated into Khwarazm peacefully before the 13th century, and had also followed the Seljuqs in their conquest of Iran. Many had been settled and would bring their military skill to battle for the rulers and leaders they felt loyal to. Turks were born in the saddle and were known as fantastic cavalrymen, especially for their skill in archery on horseback. Period art shows that amongst Turkish groups, the lance was a very popular weapon, typically wielded with both hands instead of the Frankish 'couched' style.
Bound by sworn oaths of loyalty, these men are staunch fighters.

Turcoman tribes flooded into the Iranian region following the Seljuk conquests. Originally the most reliable soldiers for Seljuk rulers, the Turcomans of Iran quickly became a liability, sometimes organizing into large masses of unruly and rebellious soldiers. They were, however, tied to the local amirs due to grazing land rights and owed military service, usually being used as light cavalry and a vanguard, showering enemies with arrows.
Fighting effectively at sea takes skill, courage, and sea-legs in abundance.
Age and wisdom are more powerful than youthful exuberance.

Crossbowmen on horseback are recorded in several Andalusian sources, but never in relation to Maghrebi Berbers - indicating a strongly regional sense of taste regarding the weapons use. Its use is attested by Ibn al-Labbana and Ibn Hudayl. Many Granadine mounted crossbowmen can be seen depicted in the El Partal Fresco of Alhambra. Andalusians also served on North African armies with their Crossbow - The Marinid army employed 200 Andalusi Mounted Crossbowmen in their ranks. ((Francisco García Fitz (ed.), João Gouveia Monteiro (ed.), War in the Iberian Peninsula, 700-1600 (Routledge, 2018) p. 45; Ian Heath, Armies of The Middle Ages: Volume 1 (Wargames Research Group, 1982) p. 135; David Nicolle, Man-At-Arms 348: The Moors 7th-15th Century (Osprey, 2001) p. 35)
These men may as well be their lord's family, such is their dedication to his cause.

The main power base of the Armenian lords, the highlands (arm. bardzravandak) house the highest portion of Armenians in the kingdom, who act as natural frontiersmen against the numerous hostile forces. Independent-minded and unruly, they are capable warriors when called upon, especially in the mountains where they have much better knowledge of the terrain.
These men defy tactics, even logic, to achieve their aims.
If you value your life, the men of the Neretva Delta are never to be underestimated.

Caravel  is a small, highly maneuverable sailing ship developed in the 15th century by the Portuguese to explore along the West African coast and into the Atlantic Ocean. The lateen sails gave it speed and the capacity for sailing windward. Caravels were used by the Portuguese for the oceanic exploration voyages during the 15th and 16th centuries in the Age of Discovery.
Born in the saddle, horsemanship comes naturally to the men of the steppes.
Wave after wave of conscripted peasants to increase numbers and drive before the enemy.
Fighting effectively at sea takes skill, courage, and sea-legs in abundance.
They will fight. Most of them will die. They have no choice in the matter.

Khwud-aspas were irregular cavalrymen that joined the mustered armies of the Sultanate, joining with their own mounts (as the name indicates, literally meaning 'with own horse'). Notable among the Sultanate forces were Mongol and Turkish adventurers looking for wealth in warfare.
Hardened campaigners, these soldiers have pledged their lives to the Empire.

The Jund are the standing army comprised of raised militia and paid soldiers either by salary, or more commonly by land grant forming military colonies. Originally in the Ummayad era, it specifically means military colonies, districts, and barracks, and the regiments it housed who were capable of long expeditions. Along time, the term come to describe the army as a whole. (The Encyclopaedia of Islam, C-G, Vol. 2 (Brill, 1993) p 601)
The hunters of the forest are gifted with both skill and courage.
Gleaming in their scale armour, cataphracts are a fearsome sight.

Dvornin/Dvoryane (Дворяне) - "Courtiers" Originally gentry, educated commoners, central treasury secretaries (diaki). The dvoryanstvo, as the lower stratum of the feudal military-service class, making up the court of a prince or great boyar, arose in the 12-13th cent. In distinction from dependent servants occupied in the noble household, dvoryane were called "free servants" [вольными слугами]. In the 14th cent. a feudal lord would grant them land for service. The dvoryane and deti boyarskie from the court of Ivan III and Vasili III became the new core of Muscovite cavalry forces, reducing the dependence on the more fickle service of other knyaz and boyars, increasing central control over the army. In the reign of Ivan IV, dvoryane could range from generals with vast estates to humble gentry with only a single peasant household on their land. [MacKenzie, David and Michael Curran. As much as he loved Sicily, he utterly ignored Germany, leaving the always quarreling german nobles free to do whatever they wanted, and thus undermining Imperial rule and authority: his successors never managed to repair the damage, and this led to the fragmentation of the Holy Roman Empire into a puzzle of semi-independent principalities

The Roki Spa  was an army of mercenaries between the 12th and 13th centuries recruited by Georgian monarchs during the wars. The term Roki was adopted from Byzantine Empire — Roga (ῥόγα), that meant cash salary, especially remunerations paid to members of the armed forces and civil service. It was probably formed after the successful military reforms of David IV of Georgia. He made provision for the recruitment of a mercenary army among Alans, Kasogs, Durdzuks, Kipchaks, Kurds, etc.They were armored in Chorasmian style and were headed by Monatukhutsesi (Master of Servants). Their duty was protection of strategic places, such as castles in frontier provinces, where they would be headed by Tsikhistavi (governor of castles). The number of employees depended on the country's economic ability. The hired mercenaries were sometimes paid with money, sometimes even in nature (shells, fowl, cattle, precious things, weapons, etc.). In order to pay a hired army, the government even imposed special taxes. Between the 12th to 13th centuries, such a tax was called "Sak'ivchak'o". The mercenaries were used by the central authorities against both the foreign enemy, as well as feudal opposition

The Ghaznavids are best known for their great use of war elephants and the Ghurid successor in Delhi would eventually adopt elephants into their military. Medieval Javan societies, like the Arabic Futuwwa and Turkish Ahi, were a cross between craftsmen guilds and military orders. They were organized as chivalrous brothers with strict moral codes, and their members would train as soldiers while also being important members of their communities, pledging their services to help build urban settlements and advancing the cause of Islam. Such soldiers sometimes made a great impression on the battlefield, like the Shia militia of the Sarbadars, who Timur thought so highly of that he recruited them after they surrendered.

The Jagir is the North Indian implementation of the Iqta system prevalent across the Muslim world. Jagirdars were expected to maintain and supply troops along with joining the Sultanate army. The Nabhani Sultanate was more of a tribal kingdom where the Nabhani were the most influential than a centralized monarchy. In Oman the tribal chiefs were ranked (from the lowest to the highest) as Rashīd, then Šayḫ, then, finally Tamīmah. The Tamīmahs would meet and form alliances with other tribes in which the alliance would be headed by the most powerful. The leadership’s orientation would be either tribal/political or tribal/religious. All these elements would then come under an overall leader called Zaʿīm al-Qabāʾil al-Akbar (“The Paramount Chief of the Tribes”). A person with this status would be able to lead and control the other tribes and compel them to submit to his rule on the basis of the alliance between them. He would be virtually a “Sheikh over the Sheikhs” (Abdulrahman as-Salimi, “The Nabhānīs: a Sketch for Understanding” Studi Magrebini 18.1 (2020) p. 101);(Abdulrahman al-Salimi, Different succession chronologies of the Nabhānī dynasty in Oman. Proceedings of the Seminar for Arabian Studies, Vol. 32, Papers from the thirty-fifth meeting of the Seminar for Arabian Studies held in Edinburgh, 19-21 July 2001 (2002),p. 262)

Yeniceri, literally "New Troops" is a result of Ottoman efforts to create a disciplined and professional servile infantry corps along the lines of Ghilman or Mamluk without needing to import slaves from abroad. Initially in the 1360-1370s were recruited through the Pencik system, a tax where the Sultan takes a fifth of all captured slaves, preferably young ones. It then replaced by the famous Devsirme system, where the state taxes youths from the conquered Christian population instead, avoiding the unreliability of prisoner of war or captive's both loyalty and supply. Devsirme provides more secure supply of malleable youths, responsive to training. (Uyar, Mesut "A Military History of the Ottomans: From Osman to Attaturk" (ABC-CLIO, 2009) pp. 18-19)

Unlike Solomon, these soldiers do not hesitate to cut a person in half with their two-handed battleaxes. Actually, they enjoy it: this is true wisdom! -- Coming from the Latin term "servientem", meaning "servant", sergeant is a rank used in almost every European army of the time (and still today). While each nation had its own technical meaning for the rank, generally the sergeant was the highest rank a low-born commoner could aspire to, since all higher offices were reserved for the nobles. Being promoted sergeant required that a soldier had survived many battles, and had performed many acts of valour (usually visible from the scars most sergeants sported), and meant better equipment and a higher salary (usually a larger part of the loot), which for most soldiers could mean the difference between returning to their homes as a serf and becoming an actual free land-owner. Usually sergeants oversaw training and equipment of small units, and led them in battle. Sometimes, sergeants were grouped together and used as a powerful fist to break the enemy lines, or to defend a focal point: well armed and experienced, these veterans are not to be underestimated.

From the twelfth to the thirteenth centuries, Georgian monarchs recruited thousands of Q’ipchak/Cuman mercenaries and successfully used their services against neighboring states. The Georgian King David IV “the Builder” (1089-1125), employed tens of thousands of Cuman-Q’ipchak soldiers and settled them in his kingdom in 1118. The settlers received land plots, summer and winter pastures, and committed themselves to sup-ply one warrior from each family.  The Cumans settled down both in the central and eastern regions of Georgia as well as in Northern Armenia, contacting closely with the local population. David married a Cuman-Q’ipchak princess, Gurandukht, daughter of Khan Otrok and invited his new in-laws to settle in Georgia. The Qipchaks remaining in the Georgian kingdom continued their military service achieving high positions at the Georgian Court. The military commander Khubasar at the time of Giorgi III (1156- 1184) and Queen Tamar (1184-1207), though for a short time, held the position of the Amirspasalar. Tamar and her successor, Giorgi Lasha (1213-1223), continued to employ Cuman-Q’ipchak mercenaries. They were referred to by the Georgians as “Q’ipchakni akhalni” (“new Q’ipchaks”)  to distinguish the newly arrived from the old settlers. ("Kartlis Tskhovreba". Georgian National Academy of Sciences Commission for the study of Georgian Historical Sources (Artanuji, 2014) 208; Hayrapet Margarian, The Nomads and Ethnopolitical Realities of Transcaucasia in the 11th-14th Centuries, Iran & the Caucasus, Vol. 5 (2001), pp. 76)

The existence of Greek militias and other troops in Constantinople in the service of the Latin emperors cannot be doubted. They may have taken several forms: (a) as guild militias, (b) as military service imposed on some groups of citizens, and (c) as formal troops. In Byzantium – as in the Western medieval cities – guilds had their own militia. While in the West these guild militias formed the corn of the military power of the cities (which strived at autonomy, if not virtual independence), in Byzantium they remained subjected to the Emperor. The guilds survived under Latin rule. (Benjamin Hendrickx, Thekla Sansaridou-Hendrickx, Indigenous and Local Troops and Mercenaries in the Service of the ‘Latin’ Conquerors of the Byzantine Empire After 1204, Journal of Early Christian History, 4:2, p. 46)

unit_description_short_texts_text_mk_mag_jund_al_nasara	Christian knights found their services just as useful to Islamic rulers as certain Berber and Andalusian contingents found the same to be true about Christian kings. After all, Rodrigo Diaz el Vivar himself famously served both Christian and Muslim lords, to take an example from earlier times. From the twelfth century to the sixteenth, North African regimes of all types frequently hired Christian mercenary soldiers to defend their persons and fill the gap of their armies neither Berbers, Arabs, nor Andalusi can fill: Heavy Cavalry. The Almohads, Hafsid, Zayyanid, and Marinid dynasties all established Christian mercenary guards over the course of the thirteenth century. These Christian Europeans in Maghrebi service were called by various names, starting with the rather neutral “Nasara” or “ar-Rum”; but also the derogatory“‘Uluj” – “Barbarians”, “Riff-raff”; or “Farkhan”. The original meaning of the Arabic word farkh is “little bird.”In a pejorative register, it could have the sense of “young man” or even “bastard.” North African and Andalusi Muslims used the term to refer to Christian mercenary soldiers.The word later entered Spanish as farfan (plural farfanes) which describes these men who were willing to trade sides in the wars that regularly ravaged the region. It is important to differentiate these Christian mercenaries in North Africa, the ones mentioned in conjunction with descriptions of the royal entourage (biṭāna, dāʾira, ḥāshiya, khāṣṣa, ʿabīd al-dār, or sanīʿa), are not just a short-term contractual mercenary, but thought of as a foreign legion in possession of the royal court. Only the monarch had the authority to recruit avowed “enemies of the faith” as personal bodyguards and soldiers. Though there were some prominent cases of apostasy, the vast majority of medieval European mercenaries in North Africa retained their Christian identities. (Michael Lower, 'The Papacy and Christian Mercenaries of Thirteenth-Century North Africa' Speculum 89/3 (July 2014) pp.601, 612, 629; Michael Lower, 'New Wars, Old Wars, and Medieval Wars: European Mercenaries as State Actors in Europe and North Africa, ca. 1100–1500', Mediterranean Studies , Vol. 25, No. 1, Special Issue: Non-state Actors in Mediterranean Politics (2017), pp. 44-46; Hussein Fancy, 'Monarchs and Minorities: “Infidel” Soldiers in Mediterranean Courts' Globalization of Knowledge in the Post-Antique Mediterranean, 700-1500 (Routledge, 2016) pp. 108-113; Eva Lapiedra Gutiérrez, 'Christian participation in Almohad armies and personal guards',  Journal of Medieval Iberian Studies Vol. 2, No. 2, June 2010, 235–250; Carl Churchill, ’ Scoundrels, Dogs and Heathens: Christian Mercenaries in the Almohad Caliphate, 1121-1269’, UCCS Undergraduate Research Journal Vol.11 No.2 (2018), pp. 24-40)	true

A tanma was a nomadic garrison force in the form of a kernel tribal federation comprising elements specifically assigned from the steppe, and associated local forces. Later other elements became part of a tanma, as more local surrenders took place. During the earliest period of Mongol expansion, such tanma were the most important form of regional control and expansion. Later, the tanma continued to exist, but formal administrative organs came into being as well, and not all surrendered populations were organized as part of it, as was the case at first. The word is apparently a Turkic verbal noun from the verb tan-, "to know, command, control. Members of a Tamma, including its commander, were known as tanmachi (Paul D. Literally meaning ‘long ship’ in the Gaelic language, the ‘long fhada’ can claim heritage from the ancient shipbuilding tradition of the Nordic peoples. Of course, the Norsemen didn’t just give their prized technology away, but their persistent raids of the Scottish and Irish coasts meant that longships were sometimes captured, enabling the Celts to study their construction in depth. Eventually, they produced the ‘birlinn’ and ‘Irish galley’, variants on the longship with between eight and twelve oars, in addition to a large sail. These features allowed the new breed of Celtic ships to easily cross the open sea for the purposes of trade and war, rather than having to remain close to the coastline at all times. Unfortunately, no remains of Celtic long fhada survive to this day, despite records of their continuous use until the 17th century.

The Ibadi Shurah military volunteers was divided to 200 to 400 men strong units, subdivided into groups consisting of ten men. At the head of each group was an educator (mu'addib) whose duty it was to teach the Ibadi doctrine and the principles of what is acceptable according to custom (ma`ruf). Every individual involved in the shurah received monthly payment of seven dirhams. Al-Salimi mentions that the low wages tended to prohibit most of the shurah from marrying; Sheikhs of Basra later produced a fatwa reducing women's dowries to ten dirhams and thus enabling the shurah to get married. Typically a good way to gain legitimacy in the Muslim world, rulers could also invoke Jihad as a way to bolster their manpower for campaigns, as there was no shortage of religious zealots and people looking for plunder.

Ghazi could be best described as Holy Warriors acting to advance and protect the borders of Islam, manning the border forts (ribats) and joining offensive campaigns for loot and glory. The coming of the Turks into the Islamic world had a large impact on the Ghazi brotherhoods however, as they settled the borders and brought the fight to the Infidels with raids and skirmishes. The title of Ghazi even became an honorific title for the Seljuks and their successors.

The mounted aristocracy is as revered in Ethiopia as it is in the Sudan. Though while their northern neighbours fight as heavy horsemen, here battles are fought with javelin, thrown with brutal accuracy and sureness of heart. The Ge'ez term "Jan" or the Amharic "Gan", meaning Royal, were bestowed to certain Sarwe regiments. Even though the regiments called Jan-Amora and Jan-Qäntäfa were associated with kings of the Solomonic dynasty, it is quite probable that their origins go back to the Zagwé days. Not only is the word jan of Agäw origin, but its use as a royal attribute goes back to this period. (Merid W. Aregay, 'Military Elites in Medieval Ethiopia' Journal of Ethiopian Studies, Vol. 30, No. 1 (June 1997), pp. 39)

Especially profitable was arms trade, in 14 and 15th century Ragusans supplied whole western Balkans with firearms, cannons and gunpowder from their own manufactories. According to local law Ragusans who owned land in Serbia had to participate in garrison duty. Ones that weren’t landowners could also help - which they often did. After all, too much money was at stake !Historically Ragusan merchants fought in siege of Novo Brdo along with its Serbian garrison. Instead of divying territories between nobles for feudal military obligation, in the Middle East it is only the taxation rights of the conquered territories were given. This system is called Iqta, and in Ottoman Sultanate, the Timar. The Muqti or the Timariot should use part of the tax revenue to equip himself and his retinue soldiers for his military obligation. Note that the land itself is still the property of the state, and the right is not inheritable, only appointed by the ruler of the state. The style used by Timarli Sipahi differs depending of their origin. Those hailing from Asia tend to be lighter, using traditional Turkish skirmish tactics. European Sipahi meanwhile tend to be heavier for charging and shock tactics. In Asian Battles, the Asian Sipahi takes the right wing and the European Sipahi the left wing, and vice-versa in European Battles. Interestingly, Timarli Sipahi also serves in the sea with the Navy.

A keen eye and a steady hand can rain death on unsuspecting foes -- Ranged troops were often thought as an unorganized rabble of peasants by haughty feudal lord being too busy in their game of glory, honour and hand-to-hand combat. This is not the case in reality, as wise medieval commanders were aware of the potential residing in ranged warfare, and organized archers and crossbowmen so that they could efficiently support their infantry. As the European powers discovered military standardization and organization, ranged forces received better equipment and training, and were assembled in companies: each company had a serjeant, whose duty was to oversee the training and equipment for the rookies and, in battle, direct the fire where it would be most effective. Often ranged serjeants were banded together as an èlite archer or crossbowmen company, and used to eradicate high-priority targets with pinpoint accuracy. Their higher status means these troops are better trained, and equipped even for melee combat, making them a force not to be underestimated

The ḥuffāẓ, literally “Guardians” were recruited childrens of tribal leaders who were trained in reformed system of Islamic law and government instituted under the first Almohad Caliphs. They also learned horseback riding, archery and swimming. ‘Abd al-Mu’min, the first caliph and founder of the Mu’minid dynasty of the Almohad Empire sought to form an elite capable of assuming all functions of administration, military and naval. He replaced the old Almohad shaykh with the huffaz. According to Pascal Buresi and Mehdi Ghouirgate, this educational system may have been inspired by Plato's Book V of the Republic. The ruling Almohads aristocracy wore characteristic costumes that allowed them to stand out from the mass of the governed. Its was so distinctive, al-Badisi once mistaken a sufi for an Almohad: “He wore a green woolen tunic, a woolen cloak of Tlemcen, a white turban and tayfiyya sandals, so that anyone who saw him mistook him for one of the Ḥuffāẓ of the Almohads. Despite their origins, the order became hugely wealthy and operated the first banking system in Europe. They were disbanded in 1307, after hundreds of Templars were simultaneously arrested and tortured in France on orders from the Pope and the King. Heresy being the main charge. A javelin is a metaphor for life: it goes up fast, it goes down even faster, then it hits you in the face, and then you die. -- In times of war, every able bodied is expected to fight for his lord, be it rich or poor. Those too poor to afford even the cheapest form of armour and weaponry are listed in the skirmishers: without armour, save for a helmet and a small shield made of scrap material, and too unskilled to use bows, these men use javelines to hit the enemy from the distance. After disastrous Ottoman defeat at Ankara in 1402. Serbia was independent once again. As sign of his new status knez Stefan Lazarević received title of Despot from Byzantine emperor. Originally it was a senior Byzantine court title, or title of ruler of vassal state, but this time empire had no control or influence over Serbia. Financed by the rich gold and silver mines, state was consolidated, and military capabilities increased.By 15th century Hungary became main source of inspiration on military matters. Ajnad al-Halqa were the non-mamluk cavalry force of the Mamluk Sultanate, recruited from native Egyptians and sons of Mamluk. Due to the fief redistributions, their lands dwindles to the point that in the late 14th century some of them cannot afford horses anymore, therefore must serve alongside the Mamluks as infantry. The constant deterioration of the Halqa reached to a point where most of the Halqa were considered unfit for duty  (David Ayalon, Studies on the Structure of the Mamluk Army II, Bulletin of the School of Oriental and African Studies, University of London, Vol.15, No. 3 (1953), pp. 451-456; Heath, Ian, "Armies of the Middle Ages, Volume 2: The Ottoman Empire, The Eastern Europe, and the Near East 1300-1500" (Wargames Research Group, 1984) p. 41-42)
